questions.question: What is the primary goal of machine learning?
options: To explicitly program computers to perform tasks
To enable computers to learn from data and improve over time
To build databases of knowledge manually
To encrypt data for security purposes
questions.answer: To enable computers to learn from data and improve over time

questions.question: Which of the following is a common type of machine learning?
options: Supervised learning
Automated learning
Networked learning
Cloud learning
questions.answer: Supervised learning

questions.question: In machine learning, what do we call the data used to train the model?
options: Validation data
Training data
Production data
Algorithmic data
questions.answer: Training data

questions.question: Machine learning is a subset of which broader field?
options: Data visualization
Artificial intelligence
Software engineering
Human-computer interaction
questions.answer: Artificial intelligence

questions.question: Which statement best describes machine learning?
options: A set of rules programmed explicitly for a task
A field of AI focused on enabling computers to learn from examples
A hardware mechanism for faster computing
The process of cleaning and storing data
questions.answer: A field of AI focused on enabling computers to learn from examples

questions.question: What is an outlier in a dataset?
options: A missing value in the data
A data point that significantly deviates from other observations
The most frequent value in the dataset
A variable with a high correlation
questions.answer: A data point that significantly deviates from other observations

questions.question: Which statistic is a measure of central tendency?
options: Mean
Variance
Standard deviation
Correlation coefficient
questions.answer: Mean

questions.question: If a dataset's mean is much larger than its median, what might that indicate?
options: The data is symmetric
There are outliers pulling the mean up
There are no variations in the data
The data is categorical
questions.answer: There are outliers pulling the mean up

questions.question: What is the purpose of exploratory data analysis (EDA)?
options: To make predictions on new data
To summarize the main characteristics of the data and detect patterns
To split data into training and testing sets
To optimize machine learning model parameters
questions.answer: To summarize the main characteristics of the data and detect patterns

questions.question: Which plot is most useful for understanding the distribution of a single continuous variable?
options: Scatter plot
Histogram
Line chart
Pie chart
questions.answer: Histogram

questions.question: What is the main goal of data preprocessing?
options: To collect more data
To transform raw data into a clean and usable format
To visualize the data
To train a complex model
questions.answer: To transform raw data into a clean and usable format

questions.question: Which of the following is a common technique to handle missing values in a dataset?
options: Discretization
Imputation (filling in values)
One-hot encoding
Feature scaling
questions.answer: Imputation (filling in values)

questions.question: Scaling features to have a mean of 0 and standard deviation of 1 is known as:
options: Normalization (min-max scaling)
Standardization (z-score scaling)
Regularization
One-hot encoding
questions.answer: Standardization (z-score scaling)

questions.question: What is one reason to encode categorical variables (like converting categories to numbers)?
options: Most machine learning models require numerical input
To increase the number of features
To remove outliers
To speed up data collection
questions.answer: Most machine learning models require numerical input

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a data preprocessing step?
options: Removing duplicates
Shuffling and splitting data into train/test sets
Handling missing data
Feature scaling
questions.answer: Shuffling and splitting data into train/test sets

questions.question: Which type of plot is best for showing the relationship between two continuous variables?
options: Scatter plot
Histogram
Pie chart
Bar chart
questions.answer: Scatter plot

questions.question: What does a box plot primarily show about a dataset?
options: Frequency of each value
The distribution (median, quartiles) and potential outliers
The correlation between two variables
Changes over time
questions.answer: The distribution (median, quartiles) and potential outliers

questions.question: Which visual would you use to show the proportion of categories in a whole?
options: Line chart
Pie chart
Scatter plot
Histogram
questions.answer: Pie chart

questions.question: How can you visualize the distribution of a single numeric variable?
options: Using a histogram or box plot
Using a scatter plot
Using a line chart with time on the x-axis
Using a confusion matrix
questions.answer: Using a histogram or box plot

questions.question: What does a scatter plot with points forming an upward trend indicate?
options: A positive correlation between the two variables
A negative correlation between the two variables
No relationship between the variables
That both variables are categorical
questions.answer: A positive correlation between the two variables

questions.question: What is feature engineering?
options: The process of training a machine learning model
The process of creating or transforming variables to improve model performance
The technique of reducing the number of features in a dataset
The step of evaluating model performance on test data
questions.answer: The process of creating or transforming variables to improve model performance

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of feature engineering?
options: Normalizing data to 0-1 range
Filling missing values with the mean
Combining existing features to create a new feature
Splitting data into training and test sets
questions.answer: Combining existing features to create a new feature

questions.question: Adding polynomial terms (e.g., adding x^2 for feature x) to a linear model is a form of:
options: Feature selection
Feature engineering
Regularization
Model evaluation
questions.answer: Feature engineering

questions.question: Taking the logarithm of a highly skewed feature is done to:
options: Decrease the number of data points
Make the feature distribution more normalized (less skewed)
Remove outliers completely
Encode a categorical variable
questions.answer: Make the feature distribution more normalized (less skewed)

questions.question: Which scenario is NOT an example of feature engineering?
options: Combining year, month, day into a single date feature
Using a pre-trained model to extract image features
Removing a feature because it has many missing values
Creating a new feature as a ratio of two existing features
questions.answer: Removing a feature because it has many missing values

questions.question: What is the goal of feature selection?
options: To create new features from existing ones
To identify and keep only the most important features for the model
To reduce overfitting by simplifying the model
Both the second and third options
questions.answer: Both the second and third options

questions.question: Which method is a common technique for feature selection?
options: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
Using correlation to remove highly correlated features
Gradient Descent
Data augmentation
questions.answer: Using correlation to remove highly correlated features

questions.question: What is one benefit of feature selection?
options: It always improves training accuracy
It can reduce model complexity and improve generalization
It increases the number of features to make the model more flexible
It eliminates the need for data preprocessing
questions.answer: It can reduce model complexity and improve generalization

questions.question: Which of the following algorithms inherently performs feature selection by setting some coefficients to zero?
options: Lasso regression (L1 regularization)
Ridge regression (L2 regularization)
K-Means clustering
Principal Component Analysis
questions.answer: Lasso regression (L1 regularization)

questions.question: Removing features that have little variance or have many missing values is part of:
options: Feature selection
Ensemble learning
Hyperparameter tuning
Model deployment
questions.answer: Feature selection

questions.question: What is regression analysis typically used for?
options: Grouping data into clusters
Predicting a continuous numerical outcome
Classifying data into categories
Reducing the number of features
questions.answer: Predicting a continuous numerical outcome

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a regression task?
options: Predicting if an email is spam or not
Predicting the price of a house based on its features
Grouping customers into segments based on purchasing behavior
Detecting anomalies in network traffic
questions.answer: Predicting the price of a house based on its features

questions.question: In a simple linear regression model y = mx + b, what do m and b represent?
options: m is the error term, b is the slope
m is the slope (coefficient), b is the intercept
m is the predicted output, b is the input variable
m and b are both constant error terms
questions.answer: m is the slope (coefficient), b is the intercept

questions.question: Which metric is commonly used to evaluate the performance of a regression model?
options: Accuracy
Mean Squared Error (MSE)
Precision
Silhouette score
questions.answer: Mean Squared Error (MSE)

questions.question: If a linear regression model predicts y = 5x + 2, what is the predicted value of y when x = 3?
What is the goal of classification in machine learning?
options: To predict a continuous number
To assign data points to one of several discrete categories or classes
To reduce the dimensionality of data
To group data without predefined labels
questions.answer: To assign data points to one of several discrete categories or classes

questions.question: Which of the following is a classification problem?
options: Predicting tomorrow's temperature
Determining if a given email is spam or not
Estimating the selling price of a car
Clustering news articles by topic
questions.answer: Determining if a given email is spam or not

questions.question: Which algorithm is NOT typically used for classification?
options: Logistic Regression
Decision Tree
Linear Regression
Naive Bayes
questions.answer: Linear Regression

questions.question: What is a confusion matrix used for in classification?
options: Visualizing the correlation between features
Summarizing the performance of a classification model by showing true vs predicted classes
Reducing overfitting in a classification model
Performing feature scaling
questions.answer: Summarizing the performance of a classification model by showing true vs predicted classes

questions.question: Which metric is appropriate for evaluating a classification model's performance?
options: Accuracy or F1-Score
Mean Squared Error
Variance
Silhouette Coefficient
questions.answer: Accuracy or F1-Score

questions.question: In binary classification, if a model predicts a positive when the actual is negative, this is a:
options: True positive
True negative
False positive
False negative
questions.answer: False positive

questions.question: How is logistic regression different from linear regression?
options: Logistic regression is used for classification problems, outputting probabilities, whereas linear regression predicts continuous outcomes
Logistic regression is unsupervised, linear regression is supervised
Logistic regression does not use any independent variables
Linear regression outputs values between 0 and 1, logistic can output any real number
questions.answer: Logistic regression is used for classification problems, outputting probabilities, whereas linear regression predicts continuous outcomes

questions.question: What does the logistic (sigmoid) function output for any input?
options: A value between 0 and 1
Any real number from -∞ to +∞
Only 0 or 1 exactly
A value that can only be positive
questions.answer: A value between 0 and 1

questions.question: In logistic regression, what is typically used as the decision boundary to classify two classes?
options: A probability of 0.5
A residual sum of squares of 0
A specific number of trees in the model
The number of features in the model
questions.answer: A probability of 0.5

questions.question: Logistic regression can be used to:
options: Predict continuous values like price
Classify instances into categories (e.g., spam vs not spam)
Perform clustering of unlabeled data
Reduce the number of features
questions.answer: Classify instances into categories (e.g., spam vs not spam)

questions.question: Which loss function is commonly used to train a logistic regression model?
options: Mean Squared Error
Cross-entropy (logistic loss)
Hinge loss
Mean Absolute Error
questions.answer: Cross-entropy (logistic loss)

questions.question: What is the output of a logistic regression model before applying the sigmoid function?
options: A linear combination of the inputs (which can range from -∞ to +∞)
A probability between 0 and 1
A label like "Yes" or "No" directly
A distance from the support vectors
questions.answer: A linear combination of the inputs (which can range from -∞ to +∞)

questions.question: What do the leaves of a decision tree represent?
options: Input features
Decision points where the tree splits
The final outcome or class labels
The depth of the tree
questions.answer: The final outcome or class labels

questions.question: Which of the following is a common criterion used to split nodes in a decision tree?
options: Mean Squared Error for classification
Gini impurity or Information Gain for classification
Confusion matrix
Pearson correlation
questions.answer: Gini impurity or Information Gain for classification

questions.question: What is a potential disadvantage of decision trees?
options: They cannot handle categorical variables
They tend to overfit the training data if not pruned
They require data to be normalized
They are not interpretable
questions.answer: They tend to overfit the training data if not pruned

questions.question: Which of the following is true about decision trees?
options: They can only perform classification, not regression
They can perform both classification and regression tasks
They require a neural network to work
They always achieve 100% accuracy on training data
questions.answer: They can perform both classification and regression tasks

questions.question: Pruning a decision tree is used to:
options: Increase the depth of the tree
Improve generalization by reducing overfitting
Add more features to the model
Combine multiple trees into a forest
questions.answer: Improve generalization by reducing overfitting

questions.question: What is the main idea behind ensemble methods in machine learning?
options: Using a single model for simplicity
Combining multiple models to improve performance
Selecting one best feature for a model
Using only deep learning models
questions.answer: Combining multiple models to improve performance

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an ensemble method?
options: Decision Tree
Random Forest
Support Vector Machine
K-Nearest Neighbors
questions.answer: Random Forest

questions.question: How does a Random Forest classifier work?
options: It uses a single decision tree with random decisions
It creates many decision trees on random subsets of data and features, then averages their predictions
It selects the best single decision tree from a random subset
It randomly changes the data labels and retrains a model
questions.answer: It creates many decision trees on random subsets of data and features, then averages their predictions

questions.question: What is the difference between bagging and boosting in ensemble methods?
options: Bagging builds models in parallel and combines them, while boosting builds models sequentially, each correcting the previous
Bagging uses neural networks, boosting uses decision trees
Boosting is for regression, bagging is for classification
There is no difference; they are the same
questions.answer: Bagging builds models in parallel and combines them, while boosting builds models sequentially, each correcting the previous

questions.question: Which ensemble method involves training on re-weighted or re-sampled data to focus on mistakes of previous models?
options: Bagging
Boosting
Principal Component Analysis
Stacking
questions.answer: Boosting

questions.question: Ensemble methods tend to improve model performance by:
options: Reducing overfitting by averaging out errors of individual models
Always giving higher bias
Using one strong model instead of many weak models
Eliminating the need for cross-validation
questions.answer: Reducing overfitting by averaging out errors of individual models

questions.question: What is the goal of a Support Vector Machine (SVM) in classification?
options: To find a decision boundary that maximizes the margin between classes
To cluster data into k groups
To construct a deep neural network
To generate decision trees
questions.answer: To find a decision boundary that maximizes the margin between classes

questions.question: In SVM, what are support vectors?
options: The data points closest to the decision boundary
The vectors that give support to the hyperplane by pointing to the correct direction
The parameters learned by the model
The misclassified points in the dataset
questions.answer: The data points closest to the decision boundary

questions.question: What is the 'kernel trick' in SVMs?
options: A method to perform classification without any training data
A technique to transform data into a higher-dimensional space to make it linearly separable
A way of pruning decision trees
An ensemble method combining multiple SVMs
questions.answer: A technique to transform data into a higher-dimensional space to make it linearly separable

questions.question: Which of the following is true about SVMs?
options: They can only perform binary classification
They can use different kernel functions (linear, polynomial, RBF, etc.) for flexibility
They are a form of unsupervised learning
They are very prone to overfitting in high-dimensional spaces without regularization
questions.answer: They can use different kernel functions (linear, polynomial, RBF, etc.) for flexibility

questions.question: In SVM, a hyperplane refers to:
options: A linear decision boundary that separates classes
A type of activation function
A misclassification in the model
A type of ensemble method
questions.answer: A linear decision boundary that separates classes

questions.question: How does the K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) algorithm make a prediction for classification?
options: By finding the k closest data points in the training set and having them vote on the class
By fitting a line through the data
By constructing decision boundaries using support vectors
By reducing the number of features to k
questions.answer: By finding the k closest data points in the training set and having them vote on the class

questions.question: What happens if you choose k = 1 in a KNN classifier?
options: The prediction will be the same as the nearest training data point's class
The algorithm will not be able to make a prediction
It will take the average of all labels in the dataset
It requires at least k=3 to function
questions.answer: The prediction will be the same as the nearest training data point's class

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of KNN?
options: It is a parametric algorithm with a fixed number of parameters to learn
It is a non-parametric, instance-based learning algorithm
It cannot be used for regression tasks
It performs an explicit training phase to build a model
questions.answer: It is a non-parametric, instance-based learning algorithm

questions.question: KNN can be used for:
options: Classification tasks only
Regression tasks only
Both classification and regression tasks
Clustering tasks
questions.answer: Both classification and regression tasks

questions.question: One disadvantage of KNN is that:
options: It makes a lot of assumptions about the data distribution
It can be slow at prediction time because it stores all training data
It cannot handle numeric features
It requires extensive training time to adjust weights
questions.answer: It can be slow at prediction time because it stores all training data

questions.question: What is the "naive" assumption in the Naive Bayes classifier?
options: That the data has no noise
That features are independent of each other given the class
That the classes are balanced in the dataset
That there are only two classes
questions.answer: That features are independent of each other given the class

questions.question: Naive Bayes is particularly known to perform well on which type of data?
options: Structured numeric data
Text data (such as for spam detection or document classification)
Image data for object recognition
Time series data
questions.answer: Text data (such as for spam detection or document classification)

questions.question: Which formula is central to the Naive Bayes classifier?
options: Bayes' Theorem
Pythagorean Theorem
Gradient Descent update rule
Euler's formula
questions.answer: Bayes' Theorem

questions.question: Naive Bayes calculates the probability of each class given the data. The class with which property is chosen as the prediction?
options: The smallest index
The highest posterior probability
The most features
The lowest variance
questions.answer: The highest posterior probability

questions.question: A key advantage of Naive Bayes is that:
options: It can handle continuous data without any preprocessing
It requires a large amount of training data
It is simple, fast, and works well even with a relatively small amount of data
It always outperforms more complex models like Random Forests
questions.answer: It is simple, fast, and works well even with a relatively small amount of data

questions.question: What is the goal of clustering in machine learning?
options: To label data points with predefined categories
To group similar data points together without predefined labels
To reduce the number of features in the dataset
To improve the accuracy of a supervised model
questions.answer: To group similar data points together without predefined labels

questions.question: Which of the following is a clustering algorithm?
options: K-Means
Linear Regression
Logistic Regression
Decision Tree
questions.answer: K-Means

questions.question: In k-means clustering, what does the "k" represent?
options: The number of clusters to form
The number of nearest neighbors to consider
The number of features in the dataset
The number of iterations the algorithm will run
questions.answer: The number of clusters to form

questions.question: Which statement is true about hierarchical clustering?
options: It requires specifying the number of clusters in advance like k-means
It builds a hierarchy of clusters either from top-down or bottom-up
It cannot be visualized
It is a supervised learning technique
questions.answer: It builds a hierarchy of clusters either from top-down or bottom-up

questions.question: What is a common way to determine the appropriate number of clusters (k) in k-means?
options: Using a confusion matrix
The elbow method to find a point where increasing k no longer significantly reduces within-cluster variance
Always choose k = 3 for safety
Using cross-validation
questions.answer: The elbow method to find a point where increasing k no longer significantly reduces within-cluster variance

questions.question: Which clustering algorithm is density-based and can find clusters of arbitrary shape while identifying outliers?
options: K-Means
DBSCAN
Linear Regression
Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering
questions.answer: DBSCAN

questions.question: What is the main goal of dimensionality reduction?
options: To increase the number of features for a model
To reduce the number of input features while retaining as much information as possible
To cluster data into high-dimensional groups
To convert continuous data into categorical data
questions.answer: To reduce the number of input features while retaining as much information as possible

questions.question: Which of the following is a common technique for dimensionality reduction?
options: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)
Linear Regression
Gradient Boosting
Cross-validation
questions.answer: Principal Component Analysis (PCA)

questions.question: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) works by:
options: Finding a subset of original features that are most important
Finding new orthogonal features (principal components) that capture the most variance in the data
Clustering data into principal groups
Normalizing all features to the same scale
questions.answer: Finding new orthogonal features (principal components) that capture the most variance in the data

questions.question: What is one benefit of applying dimensionality reduction before modeling?
options: It can help reduce overfitting by removing noise and redundant features
It always improves accuracy on the test set
It ensures the model has high bias
It increases the computational cost of modeling
questions.answer: It can help reduce overfitting by removing noise and redundant features

questions.question: After applying PCA to reduce dimensions, the new features (principal components) are:
options: Linear combinations of the original features
Individual original features selected by importance
Non-linear functions of original features only
Completely unrelated to the original data
questions.answer: Linear combinations of the original features

questions.question: What is the purpose of splitting data into training and test sets?
options: To use less data for training intentionally
To evaluate model performance on unseen data and prevent overfitting
To speed up the training process
To reduce the number of features needed
questions.answer: To evaluate model performance on unseen data and prevent overfitting

questions.question: What does k-fold cross-validation involve?
options: Training k different models and averaging their predictions
Splitting data into k parts, using each part as a test set in turn while training on the rest
Using k trees in a random forest
Using a neural network with k layers
questions.answer: Splitting data into k parts, using each part as a test set in turn while training on the rest

questions.question: Which metric would you use to evaluate a binary classification model on an imbalanced dataset (e.g., very few positives)?
options: Accuracy only
Precision and Recall (or F1-Score)
Mean Squared Error
Silhouette score
questions.answer: Precision and Recall (or F1-Score)

questions.question: What does the area under the ROC curve (AUC-ROC) represent?
options: The proportion of variance explained by a principal component
The trade-off between true positive rate and false positive rate across thresholds
The error rate of a regression model
The optimal learning rate for training a model
questions.answer: The trade-off between true positive rate and false positive rate across thresholds

questions.question: If a model performs very well on training data but poorly on test data, this likely indicates:
options: Good generalization
Overfitting
Underfitting
A well-regularized model
questions.answer: Overfitting

questions.question: What is overfitting in the context of machine learning models?
options: When a model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern of the data
When a model performs well on training data but fails to generalize to new data
When a model performs poorly on both training and testing data
When a model has too few parameters
questions.answer: When a model performs well on training data but fails to generalize to new data

questions.question: Which of the following is a sign of underfitting?
options: High training accuracy, low test accuracy
Low training accuracy, low test accuracy
High training accuracy, high test accuracy
Low training accuracy, high test accuracy
questions.answer: Low training accuracy, low test accuracy

questions.question: What is the bias-variance tradeoff?
options: The balance between the learning rate and number of training epochs
The compromise between a model's simplicity (bias) and its flexibility (variance)
A technique for data preprocessing
A method of ensemble learning
questions.answer: The compromise between a model's simplicity (bias) and its flexibility (variance)

questions.question: Which action can help reduce overfitting?
options: Using a more complex model with more parameters
Collecting more training data
Reducing the size of the training set
Removing regularization
questions.answer: Collecting more training data

questions.question: If a model is underfitting, what is a potential solution?
options: Increase model complexity (e.g., more features or a more complex algorithm)
Decrease the size of the dataset
Add stronger regularization
Use early stopping
questions.answer: Increase model complexity (e.g., more features or a more complex algorithm)

questions.question: What is the purpose of regularization in machine learning?
options: To improve model training speed
To add a penalty to the loss function to discourage complex models and reduce overfitting
To increase the number of features in the model
To ensure the model perfectly fits the training data
questions.answer: To add a penalty to the loss function to discourage complex models and reduce overfitting

questions.question: Which of these is an example of an L2 regularization technique?
options: Lasso regression (L1)
Ridge regression (L2)
Decision Tree pruning
Dropout in neural networks
questions.answer: Ridge regression (L2)

questions.question: How does L1 regularization (lasso) help in feature selection?
options: By squaring large weights
By driving some feature coefficients to exactly zero, effectively removing them
By reducing all weights equally but never to zero
By adding more features to the model
questions.answer: By driving some feature coefficients to exactly zero, effectively removing them

questions.question: What does dropout do in the context of neural networks?
options: Temporarily removes (sets to zero) a random subset of neurons during training to prevent co-adaptation
Removes irrelevant features from the dataset
Stops training early when performance is good
Reduces the learning rate gradually
questions.answer: Temporarily removes (sets to zero) a random subset of neurons during training to prevent co-adaptation

questions.question: Which of the following is a consequence of too strong regularization?
options: The model may underfit, failing to capture important patterns
The model may overfit more easily
The model will always improve in accuracy
The model complexity increases
questions.answer: The model may underfit, failing to capture important patterns

questions.question: What is gradient descent?
options: An algorithm to cluster data points
An optimization algorithm used to minimize the loss function of a model
A technique for data normalization
A method to split data into train and test sets
questions.answer: An optimization algorithm used to minimize the loss function of a model

questions.question: In the context of gradient descent, what is a "learning rate"?
options: A hyperparameter that determines the size of the steps taken during optimization
The rate at which the model learns new data after deployment
The percentage of data used for training
The speed at which data is fed into the model
questions.answer: A hyperparameter that determines the size of the steps taken during optimization

questions.question: Which variant of gradient descent uses the entire training dataset to compute each update step?
options: Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD)
Batch Gradient Descent
Mini-batch Gradient Descent
Momentum-based Gradient Descent
questions.answer: Batch Gradient Descent

questions.question: What problem can occur if the learning rate in gradient descent is set too high?
options: The model might converge too quickly to the minimum
The optimization may diverge or overshoot the minimum, failing to converge
The model will train too slowly
The model will perfectly fit the training data
questions.answer: The optimization may diverge or overshoot the minimum, failing to converge

questions.question: Which of these is an optimization algorithm that can be used instead of basic gradient descent?
options: Adam optimizer
Decision Tree
Linear regression
Principal Component Analysis
questions.answer: Adam optimizer

questions.question: What is an artificial neural network (ANN) inspired by?
options: The human brain's network of neurons
The tree-like structure of decisions
The nearest neighbors in a dataset
The clustering of data points
questions.answer: The human brain's network of neurons

questions.question: In a neural network, what happens at a single "neuron" or node?
options: It outputs a fixed value
It takes inputs, applies weights and bias, passes the result through an activation function
It stores the entire training dataset
It selects the best features
questions.answer: It takes inputs, applies weights and bias, passes the result through an activation function

questions.question: Which of these is a common activation function in neural networks?
options: ReLU (Rectified Linear Unit)
Sigmoid
Tanh
All of the above
questions.answer: All of the above

questions.question: What is backpropagation in the context of neural networks?
options: A technique for initializing the network weights
A method to efficiently compute the gradient of the loss function with respect to all weights (used to update them)
A data augmentation method for images
A way of dropping neurons to prevent overfitting
questions.answer: A method to efficiently compute the gradient of the loss function with respect to all weights (used to update them)

questions.question: One advantage of neural networks is that they:
options: Can automatically learn complex non-linear patterns in data
Require only a small amount of data to train effectively on any problem
Are guaranteed to be interpretable and easy to understand
Never overfit due to their complexity
questions.answer: Can automatically learn complex non-linear patterns in data

questions.question: What makes a neural network "deep"?
options: It has a very large number of output neurons
It has multiple layers of neurons between the input and output (multiple hidden layers)
It uses very large input data
It has high precision weights
questions.answer: It has multiple layers of neurons between the input and output (multiple hidden layers)

questions.question: Which of these is a popular deep learning architecture for image recognition?
options: Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)
Linear Regression
K-Nearest Neighbor
Support Vector Machine
questions.answer: Convolutional Neural Network (CNN)

questions.question: Deep learning models often require:
options: Very large amounts of data and computational power for training
No data preprocessing at all
Only a few data points to reach high accuracy
Manual feature engineering for every input
questions.answer: Very large amounts of data and computational power for training

questions.question: Which framework is commonly used for building deep learning models?
options: TensorFlow or PyTorch
Scikit-learn (only)
SQL
Excel
questions.answer: TensorFlow or PyTorch

questions.question: What is an epoch in the context of training deep learning models?
options: One forward pass through the neural network
One complete pass through the entire training dataset during training
One batch of data processed by the model
The time taken to train the model
questions.answer: One complete pass through the entire training dataset during training

questions.question: What is the key idea in reinforcement learning?
options: Learning from a teacher who provides correct labels for each example
Learning by trial and error, with an agent receiving rewards or penalties
Clustering data into different groups without labels
Learning directly from big data without any feedback
questions.answer: Learning by trial and error, with an agent receiving rewards or penalties

questions.question: In reinforcement learning, the program that is being trained to make decisions is often called the:
options: Teacher
Agent
Classifier
Environment
questions.answer: Agent

questions.question: Which of the following is a typical application of reinforcement learning?
options: Image classification
Board games (like Chess or Go) where an AI learns to play by playing many games
Linear regression on a dataset
Sorting a list of numbers
questions.answer: Board games (like Chess or Go) where an AI learns to play by playing many games

questions.question: What are the primary components of a reinforcement learning system?
options: Data, Model, Evaluation metric
Agent, Environment, Reward signal
Training set, Validation set, Test set
Features, Labels, Predictions
questions.answer: Agent, Environment, Reward signal

questions.question: How does reinforcement learning differ from supervised learning?
options: There is no difference; both use labeled input-output pairs
Reinforcement learning does not use labeled outputs, it learns via reward signals through interaction with an environment
Reinforcement learning only works for clustering tasks
Supervised learning learns via trial and error, reinforcement uses direct examples
questions.answer: Reinforcement learning does not use labeled outputs, it learns via reward signals through interaction with an environment

questions.question: What is Natural Language Processing (NLP)?
options: A field of AI focused on enabling computers to understand and generate human language
A database query language
A type of hardware for accelerating AI computations
A method for visualizing data
questions.answer: A field of AI focused on enabling computers to understand and generate human language

questions.question: Which of the following is a typical task in NLP?
options: Image classification
Sentiment analysis of text data
Clustering of numerical data
Solving systems of linear equations
questions.answer: Sentiment analysis of text data

questions.question: What is "tokenization" in NLP?
options: Breaking text into smaller units like words or subwords
Translating text from one language to another
Removing all punctuation from text
Encrypting text data
questions.answer: Breaking text into smaller units like words or subwords

questions.question: Which NLP technique can be used to represent the importance of words in a document relative to a corpus?
options: TF-IDF (Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency)
Convolutional neural networks
K-Means clustering
Gradient descent
questions.answer: TF-IDF (Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency)

questions.question: An example of an NLP application is:
options: Spam email detection using text content
Predicting stock prices
Identifying clusters of customer demographics
Optimizing delivery routes
questions.answer: Spam email detection using text content

questions.question: What is a distinguishing feature of time series data?
options: Each data point is independent of others
Each data point is a random sample from an unknown distribution
Observations are collected in sequence over time, and order matters
Data points are all categorical
questions.answer: Observations are collected in sequence over time, and order matters

questions.question: Which component is NOT typically part of time series decomposition?
options: Trend
Seasonality
Random (residual)
Clustering
questions.answer: Clustering

questions.question: What is the goal of time series forecasting?
options: To classify time series into categories
To predict future values of the series based on historical patterns
To reduce dimensionality of time-based features
To cluster time series data
questions.answer: To predict future values of the series based on historical patterns

questions.question: Which model is commonly used for time series forecasting?
options: ARIMA (Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average)
K-Means
Logistic Regression
Decision Tree
questions.answer: ARIMA (Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average)

questions.question: In time series, what is seasonality?
options: Long-term upward or downward movement in data
Recurring patterns or cycles observed at regular time intervals
Random noise in the data
A method of model evaluation
questions.answer: Recurring patterns or cycles observed at regular time intervals
